intro: Panicum latiglume var. decalvatum, commonly known as the hairless panicgrass, is a variant of the panicum genus characterized by its reduced leaf hair coverage. It is a perennial grass native to certain regions of Africa, typically found in open, disturbed habitats. The plant features slender, cylindrical stems that grow close to the ground, often forming dense mats. Its inflorescence consists of spikelets arranged in panicle-like structures, with bracts that are often shorter than the flowers. The botanical significance of this variety lies in its adaptation to arid environments and its potential role in ecological studies of grassland ecosystems.
